moves.1. e4: This time, I acceded to Freddy's desire to teach me a lesson on Alekhine's Defence.  We follow my recent Oxford & District League game for a short while.
moves.1... Nf6 2. d4 Nxe4 3. Bd3 d5 4. c4 Nc6: ! Freddy varies first.  In my previous game, Black never even go to move this N.  Black immediately counter-attacks.
moves.5. Ne2: rather than 5. Nf3 when 5.... Bg4 would pin the defending N
moves.5... Nf6: an unexpected retreat, but entirely consistent with Freddy's rope-a-dope strategy.
moves.6. Nbc3: developing another piece and resuming the attack on d5
moves.8. O-O: Now I seem to be well ahead with my development, at the cost of a pawn, so the gambit still appears to be working at this stage.
moves.8... Bd6: an aggressive square, the full implications of which I don't stop to consider.
moves.9... Bxh2+: and pay the price.  Now if 10. Kxh2 Ng4  11. K moves, Qxg5.  I see no point in swapping bishops when two pawns down, so decline.
moves.10. Kh1 Bd6 11. Ne4: Trying to attack while Black is still uncastled
moves.13... O-O 14. g3: played with a view to playing Kg2 and then using the half-open h-file to attack Black's newly castled king but Black quickly shows the folly of such thinking.
moves.14... Qd7 15. Kg2 Rd8: lining up an attack on my Q to worsen the effect of the threat to h3
moves.16. Bb5: ?? pinning the N against the Q but inviting a fork with check
moves.16... Qd5+ 17. f3 Qxb5 18. Rb1 Ne5: exploiting the pin on the d-file
moves.19. Nf4: freeing my Q from defending the N
moves.20. Qe2 Nxe3+ 21. Qxe3 Bxd4: another pawn ...  I could safely resign but Freddy likes to play to the end.  It's good for his opponents' souls!
moves.27. fxe4 fxe4 28. Qg4: at least avoiding the pin after 28. Qxe4
moves.28... exd3 29. b3 Qc6+ 30. Kh2: I think it was around here that Freddy announced Mate in 9.  No doubt his notes tell us exactly when!
